.dxcarpaltunne.CONTENTS: Diagnosis: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome^^^^ with paresthesias and pain but no weakness. Explained the pathophysiology ^^of this problem, the effect of repetitive motion. Discussed the benefits of using night-time ^^cock-up wrist splint(s). If symptoms resolve, no further testing is warranted. However, if ^^symptoms do not improve, recommend nerve conduction studies and a follow-up visit.^^

.dxfm.CONTENTS: Diagnosis: Fibromyalgia^^^^_Discussed nature of condition, emphasizing control rather than cure. ^^_Provided written materials^^_Advise exercise, including stretching program, walking, and upper body resistance exercise as tolerated, starting with short sessions with low speed and low resistance, increasing gradually over following months^^_PT referral for directed exercise program^^_Advise OTC NSAIDS as tolerated^^_Cyclobenzaprine [see EZScripts] ^^_Amitriptyline^^^^History: ^^Generalized aching _years _months _no trauma recalled _initiating injury ^^Symptoms worse _day _night _after exercise _with point pressure ^^Impairment of activities _missed days of work _lessened activities of daily living _sex^^^^Details:^^^^^^Exam: ^^_12/16 classic FM trigger points tender^^_no joint effusion, no deformity, no muscle spasm^^_full ROM of neck, back, extremities^^^^_Normal lab reviewed with patient^^_Normal imaging reviewed with patient^^

.dxgerd.CONTENTS: Diagnosis: Gastroesophageal Reflux^^^^Patient has heartburn, ^^regurgitation of acid, ^^dysphagia,^^chest pain,^^water brash,^^globus sensation,^^odynophagia,^^nausea.^^^^Counselled on pathophysiology, potential risks of poorly treated reflux. Advised to d/c or cut down on caffeine, alcohol, fatty foods, chocolate, peppermint. Discussed head of bed elevation for ^^nocturnal symptoms. Discussed indications for EGD or further evaluation. ^^^^Recommended ^^OTC H2 blocker^^OTC Proton Pump Inhibitor^^

.dxhp.CONTENTS: Diagnosis: H. pylori Infection.^^^^Discussed significance of the infection and recommended treatment. Diagnosis: Hypertension (New Diagnosis)
   
-New diagnosis of hypertension: bp is elevated today in clinic and has been above 140/90 when the patient checks outside of clinic. We discussed the importance of identifying and treating hypertension, the treatment targets and the personal bp goal of < 135/<85.
   
A new rx for hctz is given today, potential side effects reviewed. I recommended the patient check bp either with a home cuff or at a drug store machine 6-8 times over the next 8 weeks and follow-up with a visit in 6-8 weeks to review. If this is by home monitor, instructed to bring the monitor to the next visit so it can be calibrated.
   
At the next visit we will:
- review for medication side effects
- review the hypertension log
- recheck bp
- review the lifestyle modifications that can improve hypertension, primarily low salt diet and regular exercise
- check a bmr to review potassium, sodium and creatinine
- adjust medications if the patient is not meeting treatment targets of < 135/<85
- set up a future follow-up visit in 3 months if bp is meeting treatment targets, sooner if not

.dxpfps.CONTENTS: Diagnosis: Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome.^^^^Plan: We discussed the nature of this condition, with pictorial aids. ^^Have reviewed pathophysiology, and overuse nature of condition, role of misaligned patellar tracking in etiology, which in turn may be caused by quad weakness, such as Vastus medialis atrophy; advised relative rest during flare-up, ice, if tolerated, stop for GI symptoms.^^^^_ referred to PT for definitive management.^^^^HPI: _^^^^onset: _^^^^any original injury : _^^^^There is pain localized to the front of the knee, possibly under the kneecap; it is aggravated by going up and down stairs or hills; it improves some with rest and NSAIDs; there has been no true locking or giving way.^^^^^^Exam: _ KNEE: No Effusion by ballottement; ^^Medial, Lateral joint lines- non-tender; ^^Lachman's test is negative;^^MacMurrays maneuver is smooth bilaterally, with no "clunk", popping or grinding, Joint is stable to varus and valgus stress. ^^There is mild pain and crepitation on resisted pressure over the patellofemoral articulation, range of motion is normal with no crepitus.^^

.dxzoster.CONTENTS: Diagnosis: Herpes Zoster _ Dermatome^^^^Plan: ^^Acyclovir 800mg PO 5 x a day, x 7 days _ for analgesia.^^^^Discussed findings of Herpes zoster or "shingles. Explained etiology as recrudescence of chicken pox virus latent in the patients nerves, and then discussed potential to transmit chicken pox to non immune individuals via close or intermediate contact, until the lesions are crusted over. Discussed potential for rash to last 4 weeks, and pain to last an average of 3 months, despite treatment. Discussed potential for pain to linger indefinitely in Post Herpetic Neuralgia, and role of treatment in reducing this risk to low but not zero. Questions fielded.^^^^HPI:^^onset of rash: _^^Location of rash:_^^Level of pain, and local dermatomal symptoms reported:_^^The patient has no history of immunosuppression, recent steroid use, nor pregnancy. ^^^^Exam:^^Appears comfortable at rest. The patient is nontoxic and afebrile; See vitals below. There are clusters of vesicles in a patchy distribution in the _ dermatome on the _ side. Some hyperesthesia of the surrounding skin in that region can be appreciated.^^

.letbaha.CONTENTS: To Whom This May Concern:^^^^This patient has a diagnosis of _with ICD-9 code(s) _and the BAHA (Bone-anchored hearing aid) is the only medical treatment for their hearing loss. Please accept this as a letter of medical necessity and allow this patient to receive a BAHA osseointegrated auditory implant system under their prosthetic device benefit. ^^^^Several insurances are under the misconception that the BAHA should be classified as a hearing aid and deny this procedure based on hearing care benefits that they do not have. The BAHA is not a hearing aid, but is in fact a Class II DME prosthetic device as classified and approved by the FDA. Hearing aids, in contrast are a Class I medical device. ^^^^The BAHA is an osseointegrated auditory implant system that provides sound awareness via bone conduction. A titanium fixture is implanted in the bone approximately 50-55mm from the ear canal and allowed to create an active bond between the titanium fixture and surrounding tissue. Once this osseointegration is complete, an external sound processor is attached to the fixture abutment. Sound is captured by the sound processor and directs them through the implant that utilizes the body's natural ability to conduct sound via bone to the inner ear.^^^^The FDA has approved use of a BAHA device for patients with a blocked or damaged auditory system (conductive hearing loss, mixed hearing loss and single-sided deafness) that would not benefit by air conduction hearing aids.^^^^The CPT code for the surgical procedure is _, the device code is _, and the audiological fitting code is _. If you need additional information, please contact our office directly at (206) 341-1024. I look forward to your prompt reply to this request in writing.^^^^Sincerely,^^^^^^^^_, MD^^The Listen for Life Center at Virginia Mason^^1100 Ninth Avenue | Seattle, WA 98101 ^^Phone (206) 223-6374 | Fax (206) 625-7275^^^^

.letdexa.CONTENTS: This letter is to notify you of the results of your recent bone density test (DEXA scan).^^^^_ Your bone density was normal. Please continue to take calcium 1500 mg daily along with a multiple vitamin that contains Vitamin D (400 international unit) to keep your bones strong. Repeat testing is generally recommended in 2-3 years, please discuss with your health care provider at your annual exam next year. ^^^^_ Your bone density test showed mild bone loss, also known as mild osteopenia. While this is in the early stages, there are things you can do to help prevent further bone loss. Continue to take calcium 1500 mg daily and a multiple vitamin that contains Vitamin D (400 international unit). Weight-bearing exercise is also an excellent way to build bone.Stopping smoking and decreasing alcohol use is also helpful. You will want to discuss with your health care provider followup testing, but likely it will be recommended in 2-3 years.^^^^_ Your bone density test showed more severe osteopenia (osteopenia is a lesser degree of bone loss than osteoporosis). It does not meet our criteria for osteoporosis, but definitely is a cause for concern. All of the above information applies to you as well, for prevention of further loss. In addition, if you would like to consider a prescription medication to help prevent further bone loss, please contact your health care provider for an appointment to review your options. Otherwise, routine follow-up in 1-2 years with retesting at that time is recommended.^^^^_ Your bone density test showed osteoporosis. Please call _ to set up an appointment to discuss this.^^^^If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact your health care provider at _.^^^^Thank you.^^^^^^

.letdexa_Nl.CONTENTS: Normal: Your bone density scan (DEXA) showed normal bone density. Here are some things experts recommend to help keep your bones strong:^^- Calcium, 1000-1200mg per day, mostly from healthy foods, rather than supplements. Good sources of calcium include: dairy, tofu, canned salmon and sardines, kale, Chinese cabbage, and calcium-fortified juices (http://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Calcium-QuickFacts/).^^- Vitamin D3, 600-800 I.U. per day, typically from supplements. ^^- Regular weight-bearing exercise (such as walking, jogging, dancing).^^- If you currently smoke, stop (smoking weakens your bones).^^- Limit your alcohol use to no more than 1-2 drinks per day on average.^^Fortunately, bone density changes very slowly, so we wont need to repeat your DEXA scan for another 10-15 years.^^^^

If you need specific guidance on this you are welcome to make an appointment with our nutritionist.^^^^I recommend that we recheck these tests in 3 months after you have made some improvements in your diet and exercise routine, and have accomplished some weight loss. .letgoutdiet.DESCRIPTION: Letter Detailed Low Purine Diet Info
.letgoutdiet.CONTENTS: Dear Patient:^^^^Your uric acid level is high; Listed below are foods that are high, medium and low in purines, the ^^food building blocks that affect the uric acid level in the blood stream, and consequently Gout ^^attacks. Following a LOW Purine diet, and avoiding high purine foods can help prevent that. As ^^always, if you have any questions, contact your health care provider.^^^^^^HIGH PURINE FOODS:^^^^Anchovies.^^^^Roe (fish eggs).^^^^Fish such as herring and mackerel.^^^^Sardines.^^^^Scallops and mussels.^^^^Game meats, like goose, duck, and partridge.^^^^Organ meats: brains, heart, kidney, liver, and sweetbreads.^^^^Meat extracts.^^^^Mincemeat.^^^^Broth, bouillon, and consomme.^^^^Gravy.^^^^Yeast (baker's and brewer's) taken in the form of a supplement.^^^^^^MEDIUM PURINE FOODS:^^^^Fish and shellfish not on the high purine list above.^^^^Poultry foods not on the high purine list above.^^^^Beef, lamb, pork, and other red meats not on the high purine list above.^^^^Dried beans, peas, lentils.^^^^Asparagus.^^^^Mushrooms.^^^^Spinach.^^^^Cauliflower.^^^^Green peas.^^^^Oats and oatmeal.^^^^Wheat germ and bran.^^^^Whole grain breads and cereals.^^^^^^LOW PURINE FOODS AND BEVERAGES:^^^^Eggs (limit to 3 to 4 per week).^^^^Nuts and peanut butter: limit if trying to lose weight.^^^^Low-fat and fat-free cheeses and ice cream.^^^^Pudding.^^^^Milk: skim or 1% (limit to 24 ounces per day).^^^^Cream-style soups made with low-fat milk.^^^^Soups made without meat extract or broth.^^^^Vegetables not on the lists above^^^^Fruits and juices.^^^^Breads and cereals: low fiber, white flour, or refined grain types.^^^^Pasta and macaroni.^^^^Rice.^^^^Soda.^^^^Coffee and tea.^^^^Gelatin.^^^^Cake and cookies in small amounts.^^^^Fats and oils in small amounts.^^^^Sugar, syrup, and other sweets in small amounts.^^

.letlipidborde.CONTENTS: Your recent lab tests show that your cholesterol levels are borderline high. An individual's cholesterol target is determined by their other risk factors for cardiovascular disease such as high blood pressure (hypertension) or high blood sugar (pre-diabetes or diabetes). We monitor all the different cholesterol levels, but especially keep a close eye on the LDL level (or bad cholesterol level). Getting your LDL level below your target level can lower your risk of having a heart attack or a stroke. ^^There are lifestyle measures that you can take to improve your cholesterol. These include eating a diet that is rich in fresh fruits and vegetables and low in saturated fat (red meat, full-fat dairy products, etc). Regular exercise also plays an important role in improving your cholesterol and maintaining a healthy weight (which also affects cholesterol levels). Healthy oils such as omega-3 fatty acids (those found in fish oil) and plant stanols (healthy oils found in plants and nuts such as almonds and walnuts) have also been found to improve cholesterol levels. Recommendations are to consume about 1000 mg of EPA and DHA daily; these are the types of omega-3 fatty acids that are found in fish oil or dietary supplements. If you would like an appointment with a nutritionist to discuss this in more detail, please call and we can help to arrange that for you.^^We recommend that you repeat a fasting lipid panel again in 3 months after focusing on the lifestyle measures above. Please schedule a follow-up appointment work shortly after the lab work to discuss the results.^^

We encourage you to continue lifestyle measures that can help to maintain good heart health and good overall health such as exercising regularly and eating a healthy diet. ^^Please call your provider if you have any additional questions.^^

.letrighdl.CONTENTS: Your triglycerides are elevated while your HDL (good cholesterol) is low. Triglycerides are fats found in the blood. HDL is called the good cholesterol because high levels of HDL can help protect against heart disease. With regard to HDL, higher is better (optimal is over 50). These levels are important because high triglyceride and low HDL levels increase your risk of heart disease.^^There are lifestyle measures that you can take to improve your cholesterol. These include eating a diet that is rich in fresh fruits and vegetables and low in saturated fat (red meat, full-fat dairy products, etc). Regular exercise also plays an important role in improving your cholesterol and maintaining a healthy weight (which also affects cholesterol levels). Recommendations are to consume about 1000 mg of EPA and DHA daily; these are the types of omega-3 fatty acids that are found in fish oil or dietary supplements. If you would like an appointment with a nutritionist to discuss this in more detail, please call and we can help to arrange that for you.^^We recommend that you repeat a fasting lipid panel again in 3 months after focusing on the lifestyle measures above. .lung_ca_scree.DESCRIPTION: Shared decision-making and eligibility for a lung cance
.lung_ca_scree.CONTENTS:
Shared decision-making documentation for “CT Lung Cancer Screening”
   
Counseling (all must be discussed with patient in person/face to face for the initial/baseline screening CT):
   
-The patient has participated in a shared decision making session during which potential risk and benefits of CT lung screening were discussed.
   
-The importance of adherence to annual screening, impact of comorbidities, and ability/willingness to undergo diagnosis and treatment were discussed.
   
-The patient was given guidance regarding smoking cessation and/or maintaining smoking abstinence. The patient was informed that smoking cessation interventions are available.
   
   
Qualifying Criteria (all must be met):
- Age 55-77
- Minimum 30 pack-year history of tobacco use
- Currently smoking (or) If not smoking, quit within last 15 years
- Currently asymptomatic, no signs/sx of lung CA (No fever, chest pain, new dyspnea, new or changing cough, hemoptysis, or unexplained weight loss.)

.mmse.CONTENTS: Folstein mini-mental status exam^^ ^^ Orientation:^^What is the date: (year) (season) (date) (day) (month) - _ Points (5 max)^^Where are we: (state) (county) (town) (hospital) (floor) - _ Points (5 max)^^ ^^ Registration:^^Name three objects: one second to say each. ^^ Give one point for each correct answer. _ Points (3 max) ^^^^ Attention and calculation:^^Serial 7s, beginning with 100 and counting backward: one point for each correct; ^^ stop after five answers (Alternatively, spell WORLD backwards): _ Points (Max 5 points). ^^Ask for the three objects repeated above: one point for each correct. _ Points (3 Max)^^Show and ask patient to name a pencil and wrist watch - _ Points (2 Max)^^Repeat the following, "No ifs ands or buts." Allow only one trial - _ Point (1 Max) ^^Follow a three stage command, "Take a paper in your right hand, fold it in half, and put it on the floor." ^^ Score one point for each task executed. _ Points (3 Max)^^On a blank piece of paper write ^^ "close your eyes," and ask the patient to read and do what it says _ Point (1 Max)^^Give the patient a blank piece of paper and ask him/her to write a sentence. The sentence must contain a noun and verb ^^ and be sensible - _ Point (1 Max)^^Ask the patient to copy a design (eg, intersecting pentagons). All 10 angles must be present ^^ and two must intersect _ Point (1 Max)^^^^ Total score _^^

.pipf.CONTENTS: Diagnosis: Plantar Fasciitis^^^^Explained the pathophysiology and anatomy. recommended stretches of the plantar fascia and achilles tendon. Follow-up for possible corticosteroid injection if symptoms don't improve within a 3-4 weeks. Reassured about prognosis; Imaging not indicated at this time but may consider this if symptoms don't improve as expected. ^^

.procinjknee.CONTENTS: Procedure: Knee synovial fluid aspiration and steroid injection^^^^After verbal discussion of all risks and benefits including bleeding, increased pain, and infection, and verbal consent and request to proceed, the upper lateral aspect of the knee is prepped with Betadine and alcohol 1% Lidocaine with epi is used for local anesthesia 18-gauge needle is advanced medially from that location into the ballottable joint effusion, producing _ cc of amber synovial fluid.^^^^Through the same needle, using sterile technique, 80mg of Solu-Medrol, 1 cc each of 0.25% bupivicaine and 1% Lidocaine is injected back into the joint space.^^^^The fluid was sent for synovial fluid analysis.^^^^There is good hemostasis. The pt tolerated the procedure well.^^After few minutes, ambulation in the clinic is reported as less painful and restricted.^^^^Have discussed in detail signs and symptoms to watch for and report back to us, including signs of infection such as fever, increased redness, pain.^^

.procinjshould.CONTENTS: PROCEDURE NOTE: Shoulder injection: After verbal consent, including risk of infection, careful povidone iodine / alcohol skin preparation, and anesthesia with ethyl chloride, the _ subacromial space was injected sterilely with _ cc of 1% lidocaine without epinephrine, _ cc 0.25% bupivicaine and 80 mg Depo-Medrol. No complications.^^

.procker.CONTENTS: Procedure: Freezing of Keratosis^^^^Liquid nitrogen destruction of Keratosis: After verbal consent, including risk of scarring, liquid ^^nitrogen was used to treat the keratoses. ^^No complications. Discussed wound care. Return to clinic in one month if not completely resolved.^^^^

.procknee.CONTENTS: Procedure: Knee synovial fluid aspiration and steroid injection^^^^After verbal discussion of all risks and benefits including bleeding, increased pain, and infection, and verbal consent and request to proceed, the upper lateral aspect of the knee is prepped with Betadine and alcohol.^^^^1% Lidocaine with epi is used for local anesthesia.^^18 gauge needle is advanced medially from that location into the ballottable joint effusion, producing _ cc of amber synovial fluid.^^^^Through the same needle, using sterile technique, 80mg of Solu-Medrol, 1 cc each of 0.25% bupivicaine and 1% lidocaine is injected back into the joint space.^^^^The fluid was sent for synovial fluid analysis.^^^^There is good hemostasis. The pt tolerated the procedure well.^^After few minutes, ambulation in the clinic is reported as less painful and restricted.^^^^Have discussed in detail signs and symptoms to watch for and report back to us, including signs of infection such as fever, increased redness, pain.^^

.procsebcyst.CONTENTS: Procedure: I & D Infected Sebaceous Cyst^^^^Diagnosis: infected Sebaceous cyst^^Location:_^^size:_^^^^After discussion of findings, the pt verbalizes understanding and consent to proceed.^^The cyst is prepped with betadine, and 1% lidocaine with epinephrine for local anesthesia;^^A small incision is made at the apex of the cyst, and approximately _cc's of purulent sebaceous ^^material is produced. The cyst is significantly decompressed; the procedure is tolerated well.^^^^discussed aftercare, and follow up.^^

.procwart.CONTENTS: Procedure: Liquid Nitrogen treatment of warts^^^^After verbal disussion of pros, cons, expectations, patient verbalizes understanding and consent.^^^^Location _^^^^Sharp debridement with blade done to pinpoint bleeding, then Liquid Nitrogen applied for 10 ^^seconds x 3 applications^^^^Number treated _^^^^Discussed aftercare.^^Follow-up for refreezing in 3-4 weeks as directed or indicated.^^^^

.ros.CONTENTS: CONSTITUTIONAL: no recent weight loss or gain. No fever, chills, excessive perspiration^^ HEENT: no trouble with vision, double vision, other eye, ear, nose, or throat problems^^ SKIN: no rash, changing moles^^ SLEEP: no snoring, insomnia, daytime drowsiness^^ METABOLIC: no thyroid, cholesterol problems^^ HEMATOLOGIC: no anemia, easy bruising or abnormal bleeding^^ ALLERGIC: no hay fever, allergies^^ RESPIRATORY: no cough, wheezing, shortness of breath, history pneumonia or TB, emphysema, asthma^^ CARDIOVASCULAR: no heart murmur, abnormal pulse, chest pain or tightness. No history hypertension^^ GASTROINTESTINAL: no trouble swallowing, ulcer, indigestion, diarrhea, blood in stool, abdominal pain^^ HEPATOBILIARY: no liver disease, jaundice, gallbladder disease, jaundice, hepatitis^^ URINARY: no leakage, frequent urination, slow stream, kidney disease, history stones^^ SEXUAL: no sexual problems or history sexually transmitted disease^^ MUSCULOSKELETAL: no joint pains, arthritis^^ NEUROLOGIC: no fainting, convulsions, dizziness, balance problems, numbness or tingling, history stroke or TIA. No loss of speech or vision, weakness of arms or legs^^ PSYCHIATRIC: no depression, anxiety, or panic attacks^^

.trans_delay_p.DESCRIPTION: Transplant Delay Post Case Review Ltr
.trans_delay_p.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^^^^^This letter is to inform you that your case was presented to the Transplant Selection Committee on _ (date). Based on our programs selection criteria, it was determined that you will be placed on delay status for a Kidney Transplant pending a resolution of the following:^^^^1. _^^^^Once you have completed the above list, please contact our office so that we can review your case with our transplant team for activation. ^^^^There may be additional things that you should do to increase your suitability for transplantation. The criteria below is not all-inclusive, but is provided as a means to discuss your transplant suitability with your nephrologist:^^ BMI under 40 for kidney transplant, BMI under 30 for pancreas or kidney with pancreas transplant^^ Cancer-free for 2 years^^ Free of significant lung or heart disease^^ Free of active peptic ulcer disease, diverticulitis, cholecystitis, or hepatic disease^^ Free of severe vascular disease^^ Free of recreational drug or alcohol abuse for at least 90 days^^ Free of tobacco use (including smoking) for at least 90 days^^ Does not show pattern of non-compliance to medical therapy (patterns of compliance include taking medications regularly and showing up for appointments)^^ Ability to manage post-transplant care needs^^ Has family or friends to assist with transplant care needs^^^^Please know that there are other transplant centers in the United States that are available to you. If you would like to pursue a second opinion, please discuss this with your kidney doctor (nephrologist).^^^^If you have questions or concerns please contact me.^^^^Sincerely,^^^^_, RN^^Transplant Coordinator^^Transplant Center at Virginia Mason Medical Center^^1-800-354-9527 ext. _^^^^cc: Referring MD_^^cc: Dialysis Unit_^^___________________________________________________________________________^^UNOS - United Network for Organ Sharing, PO Box 2484, Richmond, VA 23218^^OPTN/UNOS: Your Resource for Organ Transplant Information^^^^UNOS provides a toll-free patient service line to help transplant candidates, recipients, and family members understand organ allocation practices and transplantation data. We have included the UNOS letter content below that outlines the important resources and services they provide and how to access the information^^If you have a question regarding your own medical care, you always should call your transplant center first. However, for general organ transplant-related information, you can call the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^^^ Anyone, including potential transplant candidates, recipients, family members/friends, living donors, and/or donor family members can call this number to:^^ talk about organ donation, living donation, how transplant and donation work, the donation process, transplant policies, and transplant/donor information;^^ get a free patient information kit with helpful booklets, waiting list and transplant information, and a list of all transplant centers;^^ ask questions about the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) web site (www.optn.transplant.hrsa.gov); the UNOS Web site (www.unos.org); or the UNOS web site for living donors and transplant recipients (www.transplantliving.org);^^ learn how UNOS and the OPTN can help you;^^ talk about any concerns that you may have with a transplant center and how they perform^^^^UNOS is a not-for-profit organization that provides all of the administrative services for the national OPTN under federal contract to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), an agency under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).^^^^UNOS and OPTN responsibilities include:^^ writing educational material for patients, the public and professionals;^^ helping to make people aware of the need for donated organs and tissue;^^ writing organ transplant policy with help from doctors, nurses, transplant patients/candidates, donor families, living donors, and the public;^^ coordinating the organ matching and placement process;^^ collecting information about every organ transplant and donation that occurs in the United States.^^^^Remember, you should contact your transplant center directly if you have questions or concerns about your own medical care including medical records, work-up progress and test reports. UNOS is not your transplant center, and staff at UNOS will not be able to transfer you to your transplant center, so keep your transplant centers phone number handy. But, while you research your transplant needs and learn as much as you can about transplantation and donation, we welcome your call to our toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

.trans_delay_s.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^^^We have tried to reach you three times by phone, but have not received a response from you or your caregiver. We cannot evaluate your suitability for a transplant unless we have a reliable way to communicate with you and/or your caregiver.^^^^Please call us with a reliable phone number and the best time(s) to reach you by [date].^^^^After that date, we will assume you are not yet ready for a transplant evaluation. We will close the current referral and notify your kidney doctor (nephrologist) that we have been unable to reach you. ^^^^If you have questions or concerns please contact me.^^^^Sincerely,^^^^_ ^^Virginia Mason Transplant Program^^Phone: (206) _^^^^cc: Referring Physician - _^^cc: Dialysis Unit (if applicable) - _^^------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------^^OPTN/UNOS: Your Resource for Organ Transplant Information^^^^If you have a question regarding your own medical care, you always should call your transplant center first. However, for general organ transplant-related information, you can call the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^^^Anyone, including potential transplant candidates, recipients, family members/friends, living donors, and/or donor family members can call this number to:^^ talk about organ donation, living donation, how transplant and donation work, the donation process, transplant policies, and transplant/donor information;^^ get a free patient information kit with helpful booklets, waiting list and transplant information, and a list of all transplant centers;^^ ask questions about the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) web site (www.optn.transplant.hrsa.gov); the UNOS Web site (www.unos.org); or the UNOS web site for living donors and transplant recipients (www.transplantliving.org);^^ learn how UNOS and the OPTN can help you;^^ talk about any concerns that you may have with a transplant center and how they perform^^^^UNOS is a not-for-profit organization that provides all of the administrative services for the national OPTN under federal contract to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), an agency under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).^^^^UNOS and OPTN responsibilities include:^^ writing educational material for patients, the public and professionals;^^ helping to make people aware of the need for donated organs and tissue;^^ writing organ transplant policy with help from doctors, nurses, transplant patients/candidates, donor families, living donors, and the public;^^ coordinating the organ matching and placement process;^^ collecting information about every organ transplant and donation that occurs in the United States.^^^^Remember, you should contact your transplant center directly if you have questions or concerns about your own medical care including medical records, work-up progress and test reports. UNOS is not your transplant center, and staff at UNOS will not be able to transfer you to your transplant center, so keep your transplant centers phone number handy. But, while you research your transplant needs and learn as much as you can about transplantation and donation, we welcome your call to our toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^

.trans_not_can.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^^^This letter is to inform you that you are not a transplant candidate at this time due to:^^^^1. Smoking or chewing tobacco.^^2. _^^^^Once you have resolved the above item(s), please work with your kidney doctor (nephrologist) to send in another referral.^^^^There may be additional things that you should do to increase your suitability for transplantation. The criteria below is not all-inclusive, but is provided as a means to discuss your transplant suitability with your nephrologist:^^ BMI under 40 for kidney transplant, BMI under 30 for pancreas or kidney with pancreas transplant^^ Cancer-free for 2 years^^ Free of significant lung or heart disease^^ Free of active peptic ulcer disease, diverticulitis, cholecystitis, or hepatic disease^^ Free of severe vascular disease^^ Free of recreational drug or alcohol abuse for at least 90 days^^ Free of tobacco use (including smoking) for at least 90 days^^ Does not show pattern of non-compliance to medical therapy (patterns of compliance include taking medications regularly and showing up for appointments)^^ Ability to manage post-transplant care needs^^ Has family or friends to assist with transplant care needs^^^^Please know that there are other transplant centers in the United States that are available to you. If you would like to pursue a second opinion, please discuss this with your kidney doctor (nephrologist).^^^^If you have questions or concerns please contact me.^^^^Sincerely,^^^^_^^Virginia Mason Transplant Program^^Phone: (206) _^^^^cc: Referring Physician - _^^cc: Dialysis Unit (if applicable) - _^^------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------^^OPTN/UNOS: Your Resource for Organ Transplant Information^^^^If you have a question regarding your own medical care, you always should call your transplant center first. However, for general organ transplant-related information, you can call the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^^^Anyone, including potential transplant candidates, recipients, family members/friends, living donors, and/or donor family members can call this number to:^^ talk about organ donation, living donation, how transplant and donation work, the donation process, transplant policies, and transplant/donor information;^^ get a free patient information kit with helpful booklets, waiting list and transplant information, and a list of all transplant centers;^^ ask questions about the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) web site (www.optn.transplant.hrsa.gov); the UNOS Web site (www.unos.org); or the UNOS web site for living donors and transplant recipients (www.transplantliving.org);^^ learn how UNOS and the OPTN can help you;^^ talk about any concerns that you may have with a transplant center and how they perform^^^^UNOS is a not-for-profit organization that provides all of the administrative services for the national OPTN under federal contract to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), an agency under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).^^^^UNOS and OPTN responsibilities include:^^ writing educational material for patients, the public and professionals;^^ helping to make people aware of the need for donated organs and tissue;^^ writing organ transplant policy with help from doctors, nurses, transplant patients/candidates, donor families, living donors, and the public;^^ coordinating the organ matching and placement process;^^ collecting information about every organ transplant and donation that occurs in the United States.^^^^Remember, you should contact your transplant center directly if you have questions or concerns about your own medical care including medical records, work-up progress and test reports. UNOS is not your transplant center, and staff at UNOS will not be able to transfer you to your transplant center, so keep your transplant centers phone number handy. But, while you research your transplant needs and learn as much as you can about transplantation and donation, we welcome your call to our toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^

.trans_not_can.DESCRIPTION: Not a Candidate Post Case Review

Unfortunately, based on our programs selection criteria, it was determined that you are not a transplant candidate at this time due to _. ^^^^Our transplant team supports the safest treatment plan for you. Given the possibility of operative and post-operative complications, we feel that your risks associated with a kidney transplant outweigh the benefits. We understand this might be a challenging time, though sometimes transplant is not the best treatment for all patients with kidney disease. ^^^^Even though our program does not feel that transplant is appropriate for you now, you may request that your nephrologist refer you to another transplant center. There may be additional things that you should do to increase your suitability for transplantation. .translivdonor.DESCRIPTION: 1 year living donor post donation follow-up
.translivdonor.CONTENTS: Dear _, ^^A very special anniversary is coming up: one year post kidney donation! We wanted you to know that we are thinking about you as you reflect on what you were facing a little over a year ago. Thank you for your generous gift of life; you have made a difference in this world.^^Each year post donation, it is very important that you continue your routine health maintenance including checking your serum creatinine, having a urinalysis and checking your blood pressure. You should talk with your primary care provider about having these done as part of your annual physical. If you are unable to have this completed at the time of your appointment, Virginia Mason is able to cover the expense of this lab work only. Enclosed please find a lab letter to give to your primary care physician or lab. People who live locally should go to a VM lab to have this done if possible. Billing instructions are attached to the lab slip for those of you who do not live in the Seattle area. If you erroneously get a bill for the labs, please contact me right away and send a copy of the bill so that we can take care of it.^^The United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) requires transplant centers to provide data on all living donors at 6 months, 1 year and 2 years. We have attached a form with the information that they are requesting. Please feel free to add any additional information that you think would be useful to us in evaluating our donor program. Your accurate responses will help better track donor outcomes and lead to safeguards for all donors. We thank you in advance for your cooperation. ^^We are enclosing a self-addressed, stamped envelope for your convenience. In order to meet the UNOS deadline, please fill out the questionnaire as thoroughly as possible with whatever information you have available at this time and mail it back within the next 4 weeks. Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or concerns.^^Again, congratulations one year later!^^Sincerely,^^_^^Mariza E. Turner, RN Mary Mason, MSW^^Transplant Coordinator Donor Advocate^^(800) 354-9527 ext. 32305 (800) 354-9527 ext. 10805^^

.translivdonor.DESCRIPTION: 2 year living donor post donation follow-up
.translivdonor.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^Can it really be almost two years since you donated your kidney? Virginia Mason Transplant Team hopes that this letter finds you to be in continued good health. ^^Each year post donation, it is important that you have your creatinine, a urinalysis and your blood pressure checked at your annual physical with your primary care provider. If you are unable to have the labs completed at the time of your appointment, Virginia Mason is able to cover the expense of this lab work only. Enclosed please find a lab letter to give to your primary care physician or lab. People who live locally should go to a VM lab to have this done if possible. Billing instructions are attached to the lab slip for those of you who do not live in the Seattle area. If you erroneously get a bill for the labs, please contact me right away and send a copy of the bill so that we can take care of it.^^The United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) requires transplant centers to provide data on all living donors at 6 months, 1 year and 2 years. Your accurate responses will help better track donor outcomes and lead to safeguards for all donors. We have attached a form with the information that they are requesting. Please feel free to add any additional information that you think would be useful to us in evaluating our donor program. We thank you in advance for your cooperation.^^We are enclosing a self-addressed, stamped envelope for your convenience. Please fill out the questionnaire as thoroughly as possible with whatever information you have available at this time, and mail it back within the next 4 weeks. In order to meet UNOS requirements, we need this information within 1 month of your 2 year anniversary. Also, please feel free to contact either of us if you have any questions or concerns.^^^^Sincerely,^^_^^Mariza E. Turner, RN Mary Mason, MSW^^Transplant Coordinator Donor Advocate^^(800) 354-9527 ext. 32305 (800) 354-9527 ext. 10805^^

.translivdonor.DESCRIPTION: 6 month Living donor post donation follow-up
.translivdonor.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^In many ways it is hard to believe that it has almost been six months since your kidney donation. We hope that you are doing well and that your recovery has been smooth.^^The United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) requires that we provide information on all living donors at 6 months, 1 year and 2 years. We have attached a form with the information that they are requesting. Please feel free to add any additional information that you think would be useful to us in evaluating our donor program. Your accurate responses will help better track donor outcomes and lead to safeguards for all donors. We thank you in advance for your cooperation. ^^Enclosed please find a lab letter to give to your primary care physician or lab. Virginia Mason is able to cover the expense of this lab work only. People who live locally should go to a VM lab to have this done if possible. Billing instructions are attached to the lab slip for those of you who do not live in the Seattle area. If you erroneously get a bill for the labs, please contact me right away and send a copy of the bill so that we can take care of it.^^This does not cover a doctor's visit at six months unless you are having complications and need an appointment. Please contact us if that is the case so that we can make arrangements for any necessary follow up.^^In order to meet the UNOS deadline, we mail out this letter about a month before your transplant anniversary, leaving ample time to return it. We are enclosing a self-addressed, stamped envelope for your convenience. Please fill out the questionnaire as thoroughly as possible with whatever information you have available at this time and mail it back within the next 4 weeks. Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or concerns. ^^Sincerely,^^_^^Mariza E. Turner, RN Mary Mason, MSW^^Transplant Coordinator Donor Advocate^^(800) 354-9527 ext. 32305 (800) 354-9527 ext. 10805^^

.unosactivate.DESCRIPTION: Letter to patient informing them of activation for kidn
.unosactivate.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^^^Congratulations! This letter is to inform you that you have been listed for _ transplant on the United Network Organ Sharing (UNOS) waitlist in Active status as of _. (If patient is on dialysis) Although you were listed today, you have gained wait time since the start of your first dialysis date, _^^^^As we discussed over the phone, when you are listed on Active status, you will receive a blood sample kit in the mail on a 4-6 week basis to screen for panel reactive antibody (PRA). These kits include complete instructions and must be returned within one week with your blood sample. Your dialysis nurse or lab tech can fill this for you. Please make sure the sample is labeled with your name, your date of birth, and the date the specimen was drawn. This specimen should be mailed back to the lab immediately. If you do not send the sample kit back to the lab, or the paperwork included has not been completed properly, you will be placed on the Inactive status, making you unavailable for transplant. If you do not receive your first kit within 6 weeks of this letter, please notify Bloodworks Northwest HLA lab at (206) 292-1860.^^^^Maintaining your physical and emotional health is of utmost importance during this time. While waiting for a transplant, we encourage you to live and travel normally, though it is very important that you can be contacted at any time day or night. Please make sure to always answer your phone and notify our office with any changes in your contact information, including your home, cell, or work number. Also, if your emergency contacts phone number changes, please notify us. ^^^^Please contact our office if you develop any illness or are hospitalized while you are waiting for your transplant. Call your transplant coordinator or ask your physician to send us records explaining the circumstances. You must be free from any infection or other acute illness in order to be medically safe for a transplant.^^^^Your referring physician and dialysis unit (if applicable) will be informed of any change of status while you are on the UNOS wait list. .^^^^Now is also a good time to revisit the option of considering a living donor kidney transplant, a medically favorable option that was discussed during your evaluation visit. Please see the summary of the living donor evaluation process on the attached page. ^^^^Please call me if you have any questions or concerns about your status on the transplant waiting list. We have included the UNOS Patient Information letter that outlines the important resources and services they provide and how to access the information.^^^^^^Best Regards,^^^^_, RN^^Transplant Coordinator ^^Transplant Center at Virginia Mason Medical Center^^1-800-354-9527 ext. _^^^^cc: _ Referring Physician^^cc: _ Dialysis Unit (if applicable)^^____________________________________________________________________________ ^^UNOS - United Network for Organ Sharing, PO BOX 2484, Richmond, VA 23218^^OPTN/UNOS: Your Resource for Organ Transplant Information^^UNOS provides a toll-free patient service line to help transplant candidates, recipients, and family members understand organ allocation practices and transplantation data. We have included the UNOS letter content below that outlines the important resources and services they provide and how to access the information.^^If you have a question regarding your own medical care, you always should call your transplant center first. However, for general organ transplant-related information, you can call the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^Anyone, including potential transplant candidates, recipients, family members/friends, living donors, and/or donor family members can call this number to:^^ talk about organ donation, living donation, how transplant and donation work, the donation process, transplant policies, and transplant/donor information;^^ get a free patient information kit with helpful booklets, waiting list and transplant information, and a list of all transplant centers;^^ ask questions about the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) web site (www.optn.transplant.hrsa.gov); the UNOS Web site (www.unos.org); or the UNOS web site for living donors and transplant recipients (www.transplantliving.org);^^ learn how UNOS and the OPTN can help you;^^ talk about any concerns that you may have with a transplant center and how they perform^^^^UNOS is a not-for-profit organization that provides all of the administrative services for the national OPTN under federal contract to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), an agency under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).^^^^UNOS and OPTN responsibilities include:^^ writing educational material for patients, the public and professionals;^^ helping to make people aware of the need for donated organs and tissue;^^ writing organ transplant policy with help from doctors, nurses, transplant patients/candidates, donor families, living donors, and the public;^^ coordinating the organ matching and placement process;^^ collecting information about every organ transplant and donation that occurs in the United States.^^^^^^Remember, you should contact your transplant center directly if you have questions or concerns about your own medical care including medical records, work-up progress and test reports. UNOS is not your transplant center, and staff at UNOS will not be able to transfer you to your transplant center, so keep your transplant center's phone number handy. But, while you research your transplant needs and learn as much as you can about transplantation and donation, we welcome your call to our toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361. ^^^^WHY YOU SHOULD SHARE YOUR STORY^^· You have chronic kidney disease, and your kidney function has reached the point where you are considering dialysis and/or transplant.^^· While deceased donor transplant is an option, living donor transplant offers the best chance for you to have a longer, healthier life with a functioning kidney.^^We encourage you to consider a living donor transplant so that you can be in the best of health for yourself and for those who care about you.^^It is normal to feel some responsibility or guilt about asking another person to undergo surgery that benefits you. It is normal to have fears or worries about the future health of a kidney donor, especially someone you know and care about. Many people find it difficult to ask their friends and family to consider kidney donation to them. Consider asking a friend or family member to serve as your spokesperson - a Kidney Champion (see handout). We would be happy to guide you through this process. Our team at Virginia Mason understands these concerns. Our donor team completes a thorough medical and psychosocial evaluation to determine if kidney donation is safe for the potential donor. Please ask for more information. ^^WHAT TO COMMUNICATE^^· People may not know about your kidney disease, especially if you have chosen to remain private about your health. But if they do not know your need, they cannot help. Let them know you are on or nearing dialysis and that a kidney transplant from a living donor is the best medical treatment for you. You do not need to ask for a kidney; you just need to share your story. The more people that know your story and share your story with others, the more likely you are to find a living donor.^^· The waiting time for a deceased donor transplant could be many years and your health condition could deteriorate, preventing a transplant in the future.^^· All healthy adults over the age of 18 are encouraged to call your transplant program, Virginia Mason Medical Center, 800-354-9527 x11201. There are programs to allow blood type incompatible donors to donate, increasing your chance for a living-donor transplant. ^^RESOURCES^^Living Kidney Donor Network: <http://www.lkdn.org/how_do_I_ask.html>^^Kidneylink: http://www.kidneylink.org/AskingForAKidney.aspx^^^^^^^^

.unosactivateL.DESCRIPTION: Letter to patient informing them they have been listed
.unosactivateL.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^^^Congratulations! This letter is to inform you that you have been listed for _ transplant on the United Network Organ Sharing (UNOS) waitlist as of _. You are listed as Active/Inactive status. ^^^^When you are on Active status, you will receive a blood sample kit in the mail on a 4-6 week basis to screen for panel reactive antibody (PRA). These kits include complete instructions and must be returned within one week with your blood sample. If you do not send the sample kit back to the lab, or the paperwork included has not been completed properly, you will be placed on the Inactive status, making you unavailable for transplant if you do not receive your first kit within 6 weeks of this letter, please notify the Bloodworks Northwest HLA lab at (206) 292-1860.^^^^It is very important that you can be contacted at any time day or night while you are on the transplant wait list. Please notify our office with any changes in your contact information, including your home, cell, or pager number. It is not necessary to have a pager if you have a functioning cell phone. If you are interested in obtaining a pager you can contact any pager company that provides service in your area.^^^^Please notify us if you develop any illness or are hospitalized while you are waiting for your transplant. - Call your transplant coordinator or ask your physician to send us records explaining the circumstances. You must be free from any infection or other acute illness in order to be medically safe for a transplant.^^^^Your referring physician and dialysis unit (if applicable) will be informed of any change of status while you are on the UNOS wait list. .^^^^- Now is also a good time to revisit the option of considering a living donor kidney transplant, a medically favorable option that was discussed during your evaluation visit. Please see the summary of the living donor evaluation process on the attached page. ^^^^Please call me if you have any questions or concerns about your status on the transplant waiting list. We have included the UNOS Patient Information letter that outlines the important resources and services they provide and how to access the information. ^^^^^^Best Regards,^^^^_, RN^^Transplant Coordinator ^^Transplant Center at Virginia Mason Medical Center^^1-800-354-9527 ext. _^^^^cc: _ Referring Physician^^cc: _ Dialysis Unit (if applicable)^^ ^^UNOS - United Network for Organ Sharing, PO BOX 2484, Richmond, VA 23218^^OPTN/UNOS: Your Resource for Organ Transplant Information^^UNOS provides a toll-free patient service line to help transplant candidates, recipients, and family members understand organ allocation practices and transplantation data. We have included the UNOS letter content below that outlines the important resources and services they provide and how to access the information.^^^^If you have a question regarding your own medical care, you always should call your transplant center first. However, for general organ transplant-related information, you can call the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^^^Anyone, including potential transplant candidates, recipients, family members/friends, living donors, and/or donor family members can call this number to:^^ talk about organ donation, living donation, how transplant and donation work, the donation process, transplant policies, and transplant/donor information;^^ get a free patient information kit with helpful booklets, waiting list and transplant information, and a list of all transplant centers;^^ ask questions about the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) web site (www.optn.transplant.hrsa.gov); the UNOS Web site (www.unos.org); or the UNOS web site for living donors and transplant recipients (www.transplantliving.org);^^ learn how UNOS and the OPTN can help you;^^ talk about any concerns that you may have with a transplant center and how they perform^^^^UNOS is a not-for-profit organization that provides all of the administrative services for the national OPTN under federal contract to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), an agency under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).^^^^UNOS and OPTN responsibilities include:^^ writing educational material for patients, the public and professionals;^^ helping to make people aware of the need for donated organs and tissue;^^ writing organ transplant policy with help from doctors, nurses, transplant patients/candidates, donor families, living donors, and the public;^^ coordinating the organ matching and placement process;^^ collecting information about every organ transplant and donation that occurs in the United States.^^^^Remember, you should contact your transplant center directly if you have questions or concerns about your own medical care including medical records, work-up progress and test reports. UNOS is not your transplant center, and staff at UNOS will not be able to transfer you to your transplant center, so keep your transplant center's phone number handy. But, while you research your transplant needs and learn as much as you can about transplantation and donation, we welcome your call to our toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361. ^^^^^^^^LIVING KIDNEY DONOR EVALUATION AT VIRGINIA MASON MEDICAL CENTER ^^^^The following is an overview of the living kidney donor evaluation process. ^^^^- The potential donor will be evaluated by a separate team that assesses medical and psychological suitability^^^^- The evaluation is a lengthy process to insure that the donor is not at long term risk of developing kidney disease. Please note that it takes on average from 3-6 months before the evaluation is completed and a surgery can be scheduled^^^^- A living donor advocate is a key professional who will serve an independent advocate for the potential donor.^^^^- The donor evaluation is kept confidential to the donor^^^^- The donor is encouraged to communicate directly with you, the recipient, about the status of the evaluation.^^^^- Your transplant coordinator and social worker (working with the recipient) cannot directly state if you have had potential donors contact us and/or the status of any work up in progress. We understand that this can be an extremely frustrating time of anticipation for you, but this UNOS policy insures the confidentiality of the donors medical evaluation and maintains patient privacy. ^^^^- When communicating with potential donors, please be prepared to identify your blood type and blood types that can donate to you. You may wish to direct potential donors to seek additional information on what it means to be a living kidney donor via http://www.unos.org/donation/index.php?topic=living_donation Living kidney donation - Information You need to Know.^^^^- Please direct interested potential living donors to our Donor Information Line: 206-341-1201 (800-354-9527 x11201) or via email: kidneydonorinfo@vmmc.org <mailto:kidneydonorinfo@vmmc.org>^^^^If you or your family has additional questions about living donation, please contact your transplant social worker (Lynn Rothman at 206-341-0807 or Louise Kato at 206-341-0536). ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

.unosactivateh.DESCRIPTION: Letter to patient informing them that they have been ac
.unosactivateh.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^^^This letter is to inform you that you have been listed on the United Network Organ Sharing (UNOS) waitlist for _ transplant and placed in inactive status as of _ for the following reason _.^^^^While you are inactive you will earn wait time on the UNOS list. UNOS provides a toll-free patient service line to help transplant candidates, recipients, and family members understand organ allocation practices and transplantation data. We have included the UNOS Patient Information letter that outlines the important resources and services they provide and how to access the information. Please call me if you have additional questions.^^^^Your referring physician and dialysis unit (if applicable) will be informed of your status change.^^^^^^Best Regards,^^^^_, RN^^Transplant Coordinator^^Transplant Center at Virginia Mason Medical Center^^1-800-354-9527 ext. _^^^^cc: _ Referring Physician^^cc: _ Dialysis Unit (if applicable)^^ ^^UNOS - United Network for Organ Sharing, PO BOX 2484, Richmond, VA 23218^^Tel: 804-782-4800, Fax: 804-782-4817, www.unos.org^^^^OPTN/UNOS: Your Resource for Organ Transplant Information^^^^If you have a question regarding your own medical care, you always should call your transplant center first. However, for general organ transplant-related information, you can call the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^^^Anyone, including potential transplant candidates, recipients, family members/friends, living donors, and/or donor family members can call this number to:^^ talk about organ donation, living donation, how transplant and donation work, the donation process, transplant policies, and transplant/donor information;^^ get a free patient information kit with helpful booklets, waiting list and transplant information, and a list of all transplant centers;^^ ask questions about the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) web site (www.optn.transplant.hrsa.gov); the UNOS Web site (www.unos.org); or the UNOS web site for living donors and transplant recipients (www.transplantliving.org);^^ learn how UNOS and the OPTN can help you;^^ talk about any concerns that you may have with a transplant center and how they perform^^^^UNOS is a not-for-profit organization that provides all of the administrative services for the national OPTN under federal contract to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), an agency under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).^^^^UNOS and OPTN responsibilities include:^^ writing educational material for patients, the public and professionals;^^ helping to make people aware of the need for donated organs and tissue;^^ writing organ transplant policy with help from doctors, nurses, transplant patients/candidates, donor families, living donors, and the public;^^ coordinating the organ matching and placement process;^^ collecting information about every organ transplant and donation that occurs in the United States.^^^^Remember, you should contact your transplant center directly if you have questions or concerns about your own medical care including medical records, work-up progress and test reports. UNOS is not your transplant center, and staff at UNOS will not be able to transfer you to your transplant center, so keep your transplant center's phone number handy. But, while you research your transplant needs and learn as much as you can about transplantation and donation, we welcome your call to our toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361. ^^^^^^^^

.unosreactivat.DESCRIPTION: Letter to patient information them that they have been
.unosreactivat.CONTENTS: Dear _,^^^^This letter is to inform you that you have been reactivated for _ transplant on the United Network Organ Sharing (UNOS) waitlist as of _. (If patient is on dialysis) Although you were listed today, you have gained wait time since the start of your first dialysis date, _^^^^^^Now that you have been reactivated, you will start receiving a blood sample kit in the mail on a 4-6 week basis to screen for panel reactive antibody (PRA). These kits include complete instructions and must be returned within one week with your blood sample. If you do not send the sample kit back to the lab, or the paperwork included has not been completed properly, you will be placed on the Inactive status, making you unavailable for transplant. If you do not receive your first kit within 6 weeks of this letter, please notify the Bloodworks Northwest HLA lab at (206) 292-1860.^^ ^^It is very important that you can be contacted at any time day or night while you are on the transplant wait list. Please notify our office with any changes in your contact information, including your home, cell, or pager number. It is not necessary to have a pager if you have a functioning cell phone. If you are interested in obtaining a pager you can contact any pager company that provides service in your area.^^^^Please notify us if you develop any illness or are hospitalized while you are waiting for your transplant. - Call your transplant coordinator or ask your physician to send us records explaining the circumstances. You must be free from any infection or other acute illness in order to be medically safe for a transplant.^^^^Your referring physician and dialysis unit (if applicable) will be informed of any change of status while you are on the UNOS wait list. .^^^^- Now is also a good time to revisit the option of considering a living donor kidney transplant, a medically favorable option that was discussed during your evaluation visit. Please see the summary of the living donor evaluation process on the attached page. ^^^^Please call me if you have any questions or concerns about your status on the transplant waiting list. We have included the UNOS Patient Information letter that outlines the important resources and services they provide and how to access the information.^^^^^^Best Regards,^^^^_, RN^^Transplant Coordinator ^^Transplant Center at Virginia Mason Medical Center^^1-800-354-9527 ext. _^^^^cc: _ Referring Physician^^cc: _ Dialysis Unit (if applicable)^^ ^^UNOS - United Network for Organ Sharing, PO BOX 2484, Richmond, VA 23218^^OPTN/UNOS: Your Resource for Organ Transplant Information^^UNOS provides a toll-free patient service line to help transplant candidates, recipients, and family members understand organ allocation practices and transplantation data. We have included the UNOS letter content below that outlines the important resources and services they provide and how to access the information.^^^^If you have a question regarding your own medical care, you always should call your transplant center first. However, for general organ transplant-related information, you can call the United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361.^^^^Anyone, including potential transplant candidates, recipients, family members/friends, living donors, and/or donor family members can call this number to:^^ talk about organ donation, living donation, how transplant and donation work, the donation process, transplant policies, and transplant/donor information;^^ get a free patient information kit with helpful booklets, waiting list and transplant information, and a list of all transplant centers;^^ ask questions about the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network (OPTN) web site (www.optn.transplant.hrsa.gov); the UNOS Web site (www.unos.org); or the UNOS web site for living donors and transplant recipients (www.transplantliving.org);^^ learn how UNOS and the OPTN can help you;^^ talk about any concerns that you may have with a transplant center and how they perform^^^^UNOS is a not-for-profit organization that provides all of the administrative services for the national OPTN under federal contract to the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), an agency under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).^^^^UNOS and OPTN responsibilities include:^^ writing educational material for patients, the public and professionals;^^ helping to make people aware of the need for donated organs and tissue;^^ writing organ transplant policy with help from doctors, nurses, transplant patients/candidates, donor families, living donors, and the public;^^ coordinating the organ matching and placement process;^^ collecting information about every organ transplant and donation that occurs in the United States.^^^^Remember, you should contact your transplant center directly if you have questions or concerns about your own medical care including medical records, work-up progress and test reports. UNOS is not your transplant center, and staff at UNOS will not be able to transfer you to your transplant center, so keep your transplant center's phone number handy. But, while you research your transplant needs and learn as much as you can about transplantation and donation, we welcome your call to our toll-free patient services line at 1-888-894-6361. ^^^^^^WHY YOU SHOULD SHARE YOUR STORY^^· You have chronic kidney disease, and your kidney function has reached the point where you are considering dialysis and/or transplant.^^· While deceased donor transplant is an option, living donor transplant offers the best chance for you to have a longer, healthier life with a functioning kidney.^^We encourage you to consider a living donor transplant so that you can be in the best of health for yourself and for those who care about you.^^It is normal to feel some responsibility or guilt about asking another person to undergo surgery that benefits you. It is normal to have fears or worries about the future health of a kidney donor, especially someone you know and care about. Many people find it difficult to ask their friends and family to consider kidney donation to them. Consider asking a friend or family member to serve as your spokesperson - a Kidney Champion (see handout). We would be happy to guide you through this process. Our team at Virginia Mason understands these concerns. Our donor team completes a thorough medical and psychosocial evaluation to determine if kidney donation is safe for the potential donor. Please ask for more information. ^^WHAT TO COMMUNICATE^^· People may not know about your kidney disease, especially if you have chosen to remain private about your health. But if they do not know your need, they cannot help. Let them know you are on or nearing dialysis and that a kidney transplant from a living donor is the best medical treatment for you. You do not need to ask for a kidney; you just need to share your story. The more people that know your story and share your story with others, the more likely you are to find a living donor.^^· The waiting time for a deceased donor transplant could be many years and your health condition could deteriorate, preventing a transplant in the future.^^· All healthy adults over the age of 18 are encouraged to call your transplant program, Virginia Mason Medical Center, 800-354-9527 x11201. There are programs to allow blood type incompatible donors to donate, increasing your chance for a living-donor transplant. ^^RESOURCES^^Living Kidney Donor Network: <http://www.lkdn.org/how_do_I_ask.html>^^Kidneylink: http://www.kidneylink.org/AskingForAKidney.aspx^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
